001
002package com.commercetools.docs.meta;
003
004/**
005    <h2>Middlewares</h2>
006
007    <p></p>
008
009    <h3>ErrorMiddleware</h3>
010
011    <p>The {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.ErrorMiddleware} is used to react to erroneous HTTP responses. It will always
012    be placed as first middleware in the {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.HandlerStack}. The default implementation
013    converts responses with a status code 400 or higher to exceptions. For creating the exceptions it uses a
014    {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.error.HttpExceptionFactory}.</p>
015
016    {@include.example io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.ErrorMiddlewareImpl#invoke(io.vrap.rmf.base.client.ApiHttpRequest, java.util.function.Function)}
017
018    <h3>OAuthMiddleware</h3>
019
020    <p>An {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.OAuthMiddleware} is used to authenticate a request against the commercetools Composable Commerce
021    APIs. The default implementation adds an auth header to the request instance. In case of an expired token it will try to
022    reauthenticate automatically. To retrieve an {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.AuthenticationToken} the
023    {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.OAuthHandler} is called.</p>
024
025    {@include.example io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.OAuthMiddlewareImpl#invoke(io.vrap.rmf.base.client.ApiHttpRequest, java.util.function.Function)}
026
027    <h3>RetryMiddleware</h3>
028
029    <p>The {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.RetryRequestMiddleware} is used to retry a failed request returns with the configured
030    status codes e.g. <code>503</code>. For retrying an exponential backoff strategy is used which will increase the wait
031    time before each try to avoid overwhelming the API. A jitter is also added to avoid reduce the possibility that parallel
032    requests will be retried at the same time.</p>
033
034    <p>The retry implementation uses the library <a href="https://failsafe.dev/">failsafe</a></p>
035
036    <h3>UserAgentMiddleware</h3>
037
038    <p>The {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.UserAgentMiddleware} adds an user agent header to every request. By default
039    is submits the following data:</p>
040    <ul>
041        <li>SDK version</li>
042        <li>JVM runtime version</li>
043        <li>Operating system name and version</li>
044    </ul>
045
046    {@include.example io.vrap.rmf.base.client.ClientBuilder#buildDefaultUserAgent()}
047
048    <h3>AcceptGZipMiddleware</h3>
049
050    <p>The {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.AcceptGZipMiddleware} adds an <code>Accept-Encoding: gzip</code> header, to
051    enable the ability of an compressed response as this reduces the data transport time.</p>
052
053    {@include.example io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.AcceptGZipMiddleware#invoke(io.vrap.rmf.base.client.ApiHttpRequest, java.util.function.Function)}
054
055    <h3>InternalLoggerMiddleware</h3>
056
057    <p>The {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.http.InternalLoggerMiddleware}</p> logs every request send using the SDK. Depending
058    on the configured logging level the default implementation logs the sent request and the returning response. The info level
059    outputs the request method, url and the response status code. Using debug level the request and response instance will be logged.
060    With trace level it will pretty print body of the request as well the response. To avoid leaking of sensitive data the
061    logger redacts passwords, tokens and some other sensitive data.
062 */
063public class Middlewares {
064}
